intro: Pulsatilla kissii, commonly known as the Karakorum pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Himalayas and Central Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky, alpine environments and is adapted to cold climates. Its leaves are trifoliate, with three heart-shaped leaflets, and it produces a distinctive, globular seed head. Pulsatilla kissii is valued for its ornamental beauty and is also studied for its potential medicinal properties.
